docs.title: Decker Documentation
docs.text: Decker is a WordPress plugin that provides a powerful Kanban board interface with a unique priority system for managing tasks. Designed for efficient task management, it offers an intuitive interface for organizing and tracking work items.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Decker transforms your WordPress installation into a task management powerhouse with these core features:

  • Interactive Kanban Board: Drag-and-drop interface for managing tasks across different stages
  • Priority System: Unique priority management system for better task organization
  • Task Management: Comprehensive task editing and tracking capabilities
  • WordPress Integration: Seamlessly integrates with your WordPress admin interface
  • User-Friendly: Intuitive interface requiring minimal training

docs.title: Configuration Guide
docs.text: This guide explains how to configure Decker through the WordPress admin panel.

docs.title: Nextcloud Integration
docs.text:
Access the Nextcloud integration settings at Settings > Decker:

  • Nextcloud URL: Your Nextcloud instance URL (e.g., https://nextcloud.example.com)
  • API Username: Your Nextcloud username
  • API Password: Your Nextcloud app password
  • Default Board: Select which Nextcloud board to sync by default

docs.title: Import Settings
docs.text:
Configure how Decker imports tasks from Nextcloud:

  • Auto Import: Enable/disable automatic imports
  • Import Frequency: How often to check for new tasks (hourly/daily)
  • Import Labels: Choose whether to import Nextcloud labels
  • Import Assignments: Import user assignments from Nextcloud

docs.title: Task Settings
docs.text:
Customize task behavior:

  • Maximum Priority: Enable/disable the priority system
  • Default Stack: Choose the default stack for new tasks
  • Due Date Required: Make due dates mandatory
  • Allow Comments: Enable/disable task comments
  • File Attachments: Enable/disable file attachments

docs.title: User Permissions
docs.text:
Control what different user roles can do:

  • Create Tasks: Which roles can create new tasks
  • Edit Tasks: Which roles can edit existing tasks
  • Delete Tasks: Which roles can delete tasks
  • Manage Labels: Which roles can create/edit labels
  • View All Tasks: Which roles can see all tasks vs only assigned

docs.title: Email Notifications
docs.text:
Configure email notifications:

  • Task Assignment: Notify users when assigned to tasks
  • Due Date Reminders: Send reminders before due dates
  • Status Changes: Notify when task status changes
  • Comments: Notify on new comments

docs.title: Display Settings
docs.text:
Customize how Decker appears:

  • Board Layout: Choose between horizontal/vertical layout
  • Color Scheme: Select predefined color schemes
  • Stack Names: Customize names for To-Do/In Progress/Done
  • Items Per Page: Number of tasks to show per page
  • Sort Order: Default sort order for tasks

docs.title: Advanced Configuration
docs.text: For advanced settings, you can use WordPress filters. See the Development Guide for available hooks and filters.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
If you encounter issues:

  1. Check the WordPress debug log
  2. Verify Nextcloud API credentials
  3. Ensure proper user permissions
  4. Check server requirements are met

For more help, visit our GitHub Issues page.

docs.title: Development Guide
docs.text: This guide covers everything you need to know to develop with or contribute to Decker.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin development, ensure you have:

  • Node.js and npm installed
  • Docker installed and running
  • Composer for PHP dependencies

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Clone the repository:
git clone https://github.com/ateeducacion/wp-decker.git
  1. Install dependencies:
npm install @wordpress/env
composer install
  1. Start the development environment:
make up

This will start a Dockerized WordPress instance at http://localhost:8888 with: - Username: admin - Password: password

docs.title: Available Make Commands
docs.text:
The project includes a comprehensive Makefile with commands for development:

  • make up - Start the WordPress environment
  • make down - Stop the environment
  • make test - Run PHPUnit tests
  • make lint - Check code style with PHP_CodeSniffer
  • make fix - Automatically fix code style issues
  • make check - Run all checks (lint, tests, plugin-check)
  • make package VERSION=X.X.X - Create a release package
  • make clean - Clean up the environment
  • make pot - Generate translation template
  • make help - Show all available commands

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
The project uses PHPUnit for testing. Run tests with:

make test

For verbose test output:

make test-verbose

docs.title: Code Style
docs.text:
We follow WordPress Coding Standards. Check and fix code style with:

make lint  # Check code style
make fix   # Fix code style issues

docs.title: Hooks Reference
docs.text: Decker provides several action and filter hooks to extend its functionality.

docs.title: decker_task_created
docs.text:
Fired after a new task is created.

do_action('decker_task_created', $task_id);
  • $task_id (int) The ID of the newly created task.

docs.title: decker_task_updated
docs.text:
Fired after a task is updated.

do_action('decker_task_updated', $task_id);
  • $task_id (int) The ID of the updated task.

docs.title: decker_stack_transition
docs.text:
Fired when a task moves between stacks.

do_action('decker_stack_transition', $task_id, $source_stack, $target_stack);
  • $task_id (int) The task ID
  • $source_stack (string) Original stack
  • $target_stack (string) New stack

docs.title: decker_task_completed
docs.text:
Fired when a task moves to "done".

do_action('decker_task_completed', $task_id, $target_stack);
  • $task_id (int) The task ID
  • $target_stack (string) Always "done"

docs.title: decker_user_assigned
docs.text:
Fired when assigning a user to a task.

do_action('decker_user_assigned', $task_id, $user_id);
  • $task_id (int) The task ID
  • $user_id (int) The assigned user's ID

docs.title: decker_save_task_send_response
docs.text:
Controls AJAX response after saving.

apply_filters('decker_save_task_send_response', true);
  • $send_response (bool) Whether to send response
  • Default: true

docs.title: Example Hook Usage
docs.text:
// Notify users when task completes
add_action('decker_task_completed', function($task_id, $target_stack) {
    $task = get_post($task_id);
    $users = get_post_meta($task_id, 'assigned_users', true);

    foreach($users as $user_id) {
        notify_user($user_id, sprintf(
            'Task "%s" completed',
            $task->post_title
        ));
    }
}, 10, 2);

// Log stack transitions
add_action('decker_stack_transition', function($task_id, $source, $target) {
    error_log(sprintf(
        'Task #%d: %s -> %s',
        $task_id,
        $source,
        $target
    ));
}, 10, 3);

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Decker plugin provides a Kanban board interface for managing tasks within WordPress. This guide will walk you through all the features and functionality available.

docs.title: Board Layout
docs.text: The board is divided into columns representing different stages of task progression: - To Do: New and upcoming tasks - In Progress: Tasks currently being worked on - Done: Completed tasks

docs.title: Creating Tasks
docs.text:
There are two ways to create tasks:

  1. Through the Interface:
  2. Click the "+" button in any column

  3. Fill in the task details:

    • Title (required)
    • Description
    • Priority level
    • Due date
    • Assignee

  4. Using URL Parameters: You can create pre-filled tasks by using URL parameters. This is useful for integrations or bookmarks.

Base URL format: /?decker_page=task&type=new&[parameters]

Available parameters: - title: Task title - description: Task description - board: Board slug identifier - stack: Task status (to-do, in-progress, done) - maximum_priority: Set to 1 for maximum priority

Example URL: /?decker_page=task&type=new&title=Bug%20Fix&description=Fix%20the%20login%20issue&board=board-1&stack=in-progress&maximum_priority=1

docs.title: Priority System
docs.text: Decker uses a unique priority system: - High: Critical tasks requiring immediate attention - Medium: Important but not urgent tasks - Low: Tasks that can be handled when time permits

docs.title: Moving Tasks
docs.text:
• Drag and drop tasks between columns
  • Click on a task to edit its details
  • Use the quick-action menu for common operations

docs.title: Editing Tasks
docs.text: Click on any task to open the detail view where you can: - Modify the title and description - Change the priority level - Update the due date - Reassign the task - Add comments - Attach files

docs.title: Task States
docs.text: Tasks can be in various states: - Active: Currently being worked on - Blocked: Cannot proceed due to dependencies - Complete: Finished tasks - Archived: Hidden from main view but preserved

docs.title: Tips and Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Regular Updates: Keep task status current by updating regularly
  2. Clear Descriptions: Write clear, actionable task descriptions
  3. Priority Management: Use priorities consistently across your team
  4. Comments: Use comments to document progress and decisions
  5. Attachments: Attach relevant files directly to tasks

docs.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text:
• N: New task
  • E: Edit selected task
  • Space: Quick view task details
  • ←/→: Navigate between columns
  • ↑/↓: Navigate between tasks
